Out-breath and in-breath are self-aware, out-breath and in-breath are self-cognizant; at that time it is awareness,
later it is cognizance;
Awareness means being aware of the length of the breath, cognizance means being cognizant of the arising and ceasing, coarseness and subtlety, slowness and quickness of the breath.

The awareness of the cessation of out-breath and in-breath means being aware that out-breath and in-breath will end at the time of retribution, and also calculating that myriad things and the body are born and then cease.
Cessation means the cessation of the mind.
Seeing and contemplating emptiness means attaining contemplation through practice, and no longer seeing the body.
Then falling into emptiness and nothingness means the mind has no attachments;
The mind has attachments and causes, which are cut off based on the six sense bases, and then one attains sagely wisdom.
Sagely means the body, wisdom means the Way.
Knowing where it comes out and where it ceases means, for example, like thinking of a stone coming out and a stone entering, and then the wood and stone cease.
The five skandhas are also like this. They emerge from form and enter feeling, emerge from feeling and enter perception;

emerge from perception and enter mental formations, emerge from mental formations and enter consciousness. Having distinguished these, one falls into the Sutra of the Thirty-Seven Factors of Enlightenment.
Question:
What is meant by contemplating the unconditioned path?
Reply:
Contemplation is calculation, and discernment is listening. Unconditioned means not thinking of myriad things. Path means attainment. Therefore, it is said to be contemplating the unconditioned path.
Contemplation is remembrance, and discernment is distinguishing between good and bad.
Bad is birth and death, and good is the path.
The path has no existence. Having distinguished that it has no existence, then there is nothing to do. Therefore, it is said to be contemplating the unconditioned path.
If one calculates that there is something to do and something to be attached to, it is not contemplation.
Contemplation is also for things, and discernment is for understanding the mind;
understanding the mind then knows the affairs of the twelve links of dependent arising.
It is also said that contemplation is remembrance, and discernment is calculation.
Cutting off birth and death to attain spiritual powers means that what the mind thinks is birth, and not thinking is death.
One who attains spiritual powers can fly, so it is said that birth and death should be cut off.
Attaining spiritual powers has five intentions:
First, joy;
Second, faith;
Third, diligence;
Fourth, concentration;
Fifth, penetration.

The four spiritual powers and mindfulness do not exhaust the power to attain the five spiritual powers. Exhausting the power to freely head towards the six spiritual powers is the four spiritual powers for a practitioner. Attaining the five spiritual powers and exhausting the mind can attain the six spiritual powers. Exhaustive intention means not wanting the myriad things.
First, faith;
Second, diligence;
Third, intention;
Fourth, concentration;
Fifth, wisdom. These five things are the four spiritual powers.
Mindfulness is the power, which consists of six things.

From faith, it belongs to the four bases of spiritual power and mindfulness. From joy, from mindfulness, from diligence, from concentration, and from wisdom, this is what belongs to the five faculties.
From the concentration of joy, it is called faith in the path;
From the concentration of power, it is called diligence;
From the concentration of intention, it is called intentional concentration;
From the concentration of giving, it is called practicing the path.
Because there are seeds, there are faculties. All conditioned things are evil, and then thoughts arise, unable to be overcome.
It is said that attaining concentration is the power, and it is also said that evil cannot overcome the good intention.
Extinction arises again, so it is power.
The concentration of power means that when evil intentions come, they cannot destroy;
Because of the good intention, it is the concentration of power.
When a practitioner practices the path but has not attained insight, they should calculate to attain insight.
Wherever the mind of insight is, it does not turn back, and it attains insight.
Stopping one evil dharma is sitting in meditation;

Contemplating the two dharmas, sometimes contemplating the body, sometimes contemplating the mind, sometimes contemplating the breath, sometimes contemplating existence, sometimes contemplating non-existence, in accordance with the conditions, one should contemplate discriminately.
Stopping the one dharma of evil, contemplating the two dharmas, when evil is exhausted, the practitioner of stopping and contemplating attains the contemplation path.
If evil is not exhausted, one does not see the path. Only when evil is exhausted can one attain the contemplation path.
Stopping the one dharma of evil is for knowing evil. Being able to restrain and not be attached to all is stopping, and it is also for attaining the contemplation of following cessation.
Attaining the contemplation of following cessation is stopping the one dharma of evil.
When evil has already ceased, one can then attain contemplation.
It is for contemplating the two dharmas, for attaining the four truths, and for practicing purity.

One should further cultivate purity, which means recognizing suffering, abandoning the causes, knowing cessation, and practicing the path, just as when the sun rises, it purifies and emerges through the twelve sense bases.
The sutra says:
One attains liberation through the path.
Leaving darkness and seeing light is like when the sun rises. It is like when the sun rises, one sees many things and abandons all darkness.
Darkness is suffering. How do we know it is suffering?
Because it obstructs many things, we know it is suffering.
What is abandoning the cause of suffering?
It means not creating karma.
What is realizing the cessation of suffering?
It means having nothing.
The path is clearly knowing suffering, cutting off the cause of suffering, realizing cessation, and contemplating the path.
Consciousness arises from suffering, but one does not grasp at suffering, and there is also no consciousness. This is suffering.
Realizing cessation means knowing the end of a person.
The realization of old age, sickness, and death means knowing that all things will perish. This is realizing cessation.
It is like when the sun rises, it performs four things:
First, it destroys darkness. Wisdom can destroy ignorance.
Second, it sees light. Ignorance is removed and only wisdom remains.
Third, it sees the myriad things. It sees the various impurities of the body.
Fourth, maturing myriad things. If there were no sun and moon, myriad things would not ripen;
People would have no wisdom or foolishness, and their minds would also not mature.
As for the practice of both, one practices what should be done, without discriminating or explaining, namely practicing the five direct sounds, and both body and mind attain practice.
From contemplating the Dharma, the mind becomes attached to the Dharma;
From contemplating the Dharma, the mind becomes attached to what is thought, and then gives rise to this. Seeking birth and death, one attains birth and death; seeking the Way, one attains the Way.
Following the arising of the mind, whether internally or externally, this is called contemplating the Dharma.

As for the mind becoming attached to the Dharma, from the four truths one knows the mind arises by oneself, this is to be attained, this is not to be born, this is not to be obtained, this is to be turned back, the mind fears and dares not violate.
What is practiced and contemplated is always in the Way, this is called the mind becoming attached to the Dharma.
This is called the Dharma, which arises from the original truth, and the original mind is attached to it.
As for the correct Dharma, it refers to the Dharma of the Way.
From truth, referring to the Four Truths.
The mind that originally gives rise to attachment means that all the myriad things in birth and death originate from the mind.
If one becomes attached to the mind, then the five aggregates will arise.
The mind should be cut off, and if the root is cut off, the five aggregates will also be cut off.
Sometimes it is cut off by itself, but the mind still arises and creates offenses. It is not fixed in the path because it is not yet exhausted.
The mind attached to dharmas means that if the mind contemplates myriad things, it falls into external dharmas. If the mind does not contemplate myriad things, it falls into the dharmas of the path.
The five aggregates are the dharmas of birth and death, and the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment are the dharmas of the path.
The mind attached to dharmas means controlling the five aggregates without transgression, and always contemplating the path without separation. This is called the mind attached to dharmas.
The original basis is correct. Being external, it is the basis for things, which is meritorious;
being internal, it is the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment in total. Practicing the path is not a single moment of uprightness.

As for the basis, it refers to practicing the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment as taught in the sutras, following the sequence, and not letting the mind enter into evil but keeping it in the right, therefore it is called the basis of rightness.
The basis and rightness each have different practices. Using non-action as the basis and non-seeking as the rightness;

Using non-action as the basis and non-permanence as the rightness; Using non-existence as the basis and non-existence as the rightness, and also non-existence as the basis and non-rightness as the rightness, is to be without anything.
The concentration, enlightenment, and acceptance of the body, such Dharma and path, are called the Dharma of concentration.
The teaching of the path refers to teaching the path that is attained from causes and conditions.
The one who accepts the aggregates is the one who accepts the five aggregates.
The one who enters is the one who enters into the five aggregates.
The one who is caused by the aggregates of birth and death is the one who accepts the right;
The right means the path is right by itself, one should only make one's own mind right.
When a person practices mindfulness of breathing, they attain counting, attainment, and stopping, and then rejoice. These are the four kinds.
It is like drilling for fire and seeing smoke, but not being able to cook things. What kind of joy is attained?
Because the essential method has not yet been obtained.
Mindfulness of breathing has eighteen afflictions that cause people not to follow the Way:

First, desire, second, anger, third, delusion, fourth, playfulness, fifth, arrogance, sixth, doubt, seventh, not practicing the characteristics, eighth, accepting the characteristics of others, ninth, lack of mindfulness, tenth, other thoughts, eleventh, incomplete thoughts, twelfth, excessive effort, thirteenth, insufficient effort, fourteenth, fear, fifteenth, forcing the mind, sixteenth, worry, seventeenth, haste, and eighteenth, not crossing over the mind's love of practice. These are the eighteen afflictions.
Not guarding is the eighteen causes and conditions for not attaining the Way, but by guarding one attains the Way.

The characteristic of non-acceptance of practice refers to not contemplating the thirty-two things and not thinking of the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, which is called the characteristic of non-acceptance of practice.
The characteristic of accepting others refers to practicing the characteristics of following the breath before attaining the ten breaths, which is called the characteristic of accepting others.
Other thoughts means thinking of exhalation when inhaling and thinking of inhalation when exhaling, which is called other thoughts.
Incomplete thoughts means thinking of the second dhyÄna before attaining the first dhyÄna, which is called incomplete thoughts.
Forcing the mind means when sitting in confusion, the mind cannot be at peace, one should walk or read sÅ«tras to prevent confusion from arising, which is called forcing the mind.
Diligence is wisdom. Running among these six things refers to counting the breath, following, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying, which are the six.ğŸ”½What is panting?
What is breathing?
What is qi?
What is power?
What is wind?

Panting is the breath of the mind, the guard of life, qi, the wind of seeing and hearing, the ability to speak, the power to bend and stretch along the path, and the ability to lift heavy objects and become angry.
One must attain the Way through guarding the mind. What is the basis for guarding the mind?
From counting, one attains the turning of the breath. From the turning of the breath, one attains following. Stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying are also like this.
When practicing the Way and wanting to stop the mind, one should know three things:
First, first contemplate where the body originally comes from. It only comes from the five aggregates. When the five aggregates are cut off, it does not arise again;
It is like a temporary entrustment. The mind does not understand, but contemplates the nine paths to realize itself.
Second, one should internally observe the mind following the breath as it comes and goes.
Third, when the thought of exhalation and inhalation ceases.
When exhalation is slightly light and the thought ceases, what is it to know of non-existence?
If the mind is concentrated, one will know emptiness. Knowing emptiness, one will know non-existence.
Why is it so?
If the breath stops, one will die. Knowing that the body is merely created by qi, and the qi dissipates into emptiness, one realizes emptiness and enters the Way.
Therefore, there are three things in practicing the Way:
First, contemplating the body;
Second, being mindful of the one mind;
Third, being mindful of the inhalation and exhalation of breath.
There are also three more things:
First, stopping bodily pain and itching;
Second, stopping verbal sounds;
Third, stopping mental thoughts and activities. These six things can quickly lead to the cessation of breath.
The sutra says:
One thought refers to the one mind, close thought refers to contemplating the body, many thoughts refer to the one mind, and inseparable thought refers to not being apart from thought.

If one practices these four things with the body, one can quickly attain the cessation of breath.ğŸ”½Counting the breath while sitting in meditation immediately leads to concentration, which is the present blessing;
Ultimately attaining peace and non-disturbance is the future blessing;
If it continues and becomes stable after a long time, this is past merit.
If one is unable to attain concentration while counting the breath in meditation, this is a present offense;
If one subsequently becomes restless and agitated, this is a future offense;
If one continues in meditation for a long time but still becomes restless, this is a past offense.
There are also offenses of body and mind:
If one is unable to count the breath while sitting upright, this is a mental offense;
If one is unable to count the breath while sitting crookedly, this is a physical offense.
When meditating, one should know that a joyful mind is a distracted mind, and a non-joyful mind is the mind of the Way.
When meditating, after the breath has stopped, one should contemplate; after contemplating, one should resume the breath.
When practicing the Way, one should always follow these principles.
The Buddha said there are five kinds of faith:
First, believing in the existence of the Buddha and the sutras;
Second, leaving home and shaving one's head to seek the Way;
Third, sitting and practicing the Way; fourth, attaining the breath;
Fifth, attaining concentration.
What is contemplated is empty, and what is not contemplated is also empty.
Why contemplate the breath?
The answer:
In the breath there are no five desires, lust, anger, ignorance, and love, and this is also empty.
The mind in the body that can be guarded refers to the mind observing in the body, which is the mind in the body.
Because people cannot control their minds, they are made to count the breath. With wisdom, they can control their minds and no longer count the breath.
Question:ğŸ”½What is self-knowledge?
What is self-realization?
The answer:
Being able to discern the five skandhas is self-knowledge, and not doubting the Way is self-realization.
The question:
What is unconditioned?
The answer:
There are two kinds of unconditioned:
There is external unconditioned, and there is internal unconditioned.

The eyes do not see forms, the ears do not hear sounds, the nose does not smell fragrances, the mouth does not taste flavors, the body does not crave smoothness, and the mind does not think - this is the external non-action;
Counting the breath, following, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying - this is the internal non-action.
Question:
Since there are thoughts present, how can it be considered non-action?
Reply:
The body and mouth are for precepts, the mind is directed towards the practice of the Way. Although there are thoughts, the basis is directed towards non-action.
Question:
What is meant by non?
What is meant by action?
Reply:
Non refers to not thinking of myriad things;
Action refers to following the sutra practices and calling out the names of events, thus it is called non-action.
Question:
If the karmic retribution from past lives comes, how can it be averted?
Reply:
By practicing counting the breath, following, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying, and contemplating the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, it can be averted.
Objection:
The retribution of past lives cannot be avoided, but by practicing counting breaths and the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, one can avoid them. Why is this so?
The answer:
Because of contemplating the Way, evil is eliminated.
If counting breaths, following, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying could not eliminate evil, then all worldly people would not attain the Way;
Because it eliminates evil, one attains the Way.

Even if one practices counting breaths, following, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying, and the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, one can still become a Buddha, let alone the retribution of offenses, which are accumulated like mountains in the ten directions. If one diligently practices the Way, one will not encounter offenses.
Question:
The sutra says, By doing this, why do you not encounter them?
The answer:
Because of doing this.
Counting breaths falls into twelve categories.
What are the twelve categories?ğŸ”½When counting breaths, one falls into the four foundations of mindfulness;
When the breath is not chaotic, one falls into the four right efforts and attains ten breaths;
Sometimes it falls into the four bases of supernatural power, which is falling into the twelve divisions.
Question:
What are the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment?
Reply:
It refers to counting the breath, following, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying. Practicing these six things is the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.
Practicing counting the breath is also practicing the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.
Question:
Why is it practicing the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment?
Reply:
Counting the breath falls into the four establishments of mindfulness.
Why is it so?
Because the four establishments of mindfulness also fall into the four right efforts, it is the four right efforts because it does not wait for mindfulness;
it also falls into the four bases of supernatural power because it follows faith, so it is the bases of supernatural power.
Counting the breath falls into the faculty of faith because believing in the Buddha's intention brings joy, so the faculty of faith arises;
it also falls into the faculty of energy because sitting practice causes it to fall into the faculty of energy;
It also falls into the faculty of consciousness, using knowledge to understand the truth, thus it becomes the faculty of consciousness;
It also falls into the faculty of concentration, using the mind to be at ease, thus it becomes the faculty of concentration;
It also falls into the faculty of wisdom, using the mind free from delusion to untie knots, thus it becomes the faculty of wisdom.
Counting the breath also falls into the power of faith, using non-doubt, thus it becomes the power of faith;
It also falls into the power of effort, using diligence, thus it becomes the power of effort;
It also falls into the power of mindfulness, using other thoughts that cannot be removed, thus it becomes the power of mindfulness;
It also falls into the power of concentration, using single-mindedness, thus it becomes the power of concentration;

It also falls into the power of wisdom, using the previous distinctions of the four foundations of mindfulness, the four right efforts, and the four bases of supernatural power, thus it becomes the power of wisdom.
Counting the breath also falls into the factors of enlightenment.
Using the recognition of suffering, it becomes the factor of enlightenment;

It also falls into the factor of enlightenment of the recognition of dharmas, using the knowledge of the causes and conditions of the path, it becomes the factor of enlightenment of the recognition of dharmas;
It also falls into the factor of enlightenment of effort, using the abandonment of evil, it becomes the factor of enlightenment of effort;

It also falls into the intention of love, using greed and pleasure as the path, thus it becomes the intention of love;ğŸ”½It also falls into the intention of cessation, using concentration to stop, thus it becomes the intention of cessation;ğŸ”½It also falls into the intention of concentration, using non-thought, thus it becomes the intention of concentration;
It also falls into the intention of guarding, using practice to not depart, thus it becomes the intention of guarding.
Counting the breath also falls into the eight practices, using the mind correctly, thus entering the eight practices.
Concentration, loving-kindness, and mindfulness of pure dharmas are upright body;
Truthful speech, gentle speech, straightforward speech, and non-retaliatory speech are upright speech.
Wisdom in the mind, faith in the mind, and patience in the mind are upright mind.
What is meant by the sound and breath is the ten wholesome practices that fall into the path.
Counting the breath also falls into right view, using true observation, thus it becomes right view;
It also falls into right practice, using the path, thus it becomes right practice;
It also falls into right practice, because it practices the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, it is right practice;
It also falls into right intention, because it contemplates the truths, it is right intention;
It also falls into right concentration, because it uses pure thoughts to destroy the army of demons, it is right concentration. These are the eight practices.
What is the army of demons?
It refers to form, sound, smell, taste, and touch, this is the army of demons.
Not accepting it is called destroying the army of demons.

The thirty-seven factors of enlightenment should be gathered. If one contemplates one's own body and the bodies of others, one stops lust and does not disturb the mind, one stops the remaining thoughts;
If one contemplates one's own feelings and the feelings of others, one stops anger;
If one contemplates one's own mind and the minds of others, one stops delusion;
If one contemplates one's own Dharma and the Dharma of others, one attains the Way. This is called the four establishments of mindfulness.

Avoiding the body is avoiding form, avoiding pain is avoiding the five desires, avoiding the mind is avoiding thoughts, and avoiding the Dharma is not falling into the karma of vows and livelihood. This is called the four right efforts.
Recognizing suffering means the root is suffering, and suffering means having a body.
What arises from suffering as a cause is the myriad things that are seen.
The accumulation of suffering means the root is suffering, and what arises from suffering as a cause.
Extinction means all things will perish.
Increasing the accumulation of suffering will lead to falling into the eightfold path.
The practitioner should contemplate this eightfold path, which is called the four, which includes suffering and attains the four bases of supernatural power and mindfulness.
Joyfully believing in the Buddha's intention is called the root of faith.
Self-guarding and practicing the Dharma, and receiving the body and mind from the truth, is called the root of energy, which is diligence;
From the truth, mindfulness follows the truth, this is called the root of recognition, which is guarding the mind;
Following the truth with a single thought, and stopping with a single thought of the truth, this is called the faculty of concentration, which is right thought;
Following the truth and contemplating the truth, this is called the faculty of wisdom, which is the thought of the Way. These are called the five faculties.
Following the truth with faith and no longer doubting, this is called the power of faith;
Abandoning greed and practicing the Way, following the truth and diligently advancing oneself, with evil thoughts unable to destroy one's diligence, this is called the power of diligence;
When evil thoughts are about to arise, they should be immediately extinguished. Following the truth, this mind cannot be destroyed, and this is called the power of mindfulness;
Contemplating internally and externally, following the truth and attaining concentration, with evil thoughts unable to destroy the good mind, this is called the power of concentration;
Mindfully recollecting the four meditations, following the truth and attaining wisdom, with evil thoughts unable to destroy the wise mind, this is called the power of wisdom.
Mindfully recollecting the end of coming and going and rebirth, these are called the five powers.ğŸ”½Following the truth and recollecting the truth, this is called the factor of enlightenment.
Attaining the thought of the Way, following the truth and contemplating the truth, this is called the factor of enlightenment of the Dharma and the discernment of the Dharma;
Attaining the intention of birth and death, upholding the body and mind from the truths, this is called the power of enlightenment;
Upholding the Way without losing it is power. From the joy of the bases of supernormal power, this is called the love of enlightenment;

Craving the Dharma of the Way, practicing the Way, practicing the Dharma of the Way, from the mind attaining rest from the truths, this is called the intention of rest. Having rested and peacefully from the truths, this is called the concentration of enlightenment;
Knowing the mind, stabilizing it from the truths, the mind being at ease in what it practices from contemplation, this is called the intention of guarding.
From contemplating the four truths, this is called the seven factors of enlightenment.
From guarding the truths, this is called the straight faith path;
From the truths, from practicing the truths, this is the straight practice mindfulness path;
From upholding the body and mind from the truths, this is called the straight practice.
Those who do not wish to fall into the four evil destinies refer to the four inverted views.ğŸ”½From the mindfulness of the truths, this is called the straight mind, the unconfused mind;
From the one-pointed mind of the truths, this is called the straight concentration.

It is the foremost of the one-pointed mind, the practice of the three dharmas, and the practice of the eightfold path with the voice, body, and mind. The Buddha's disciples practice these eight, which are called the four dhyÄnas, and the four right efforts.
The first practice is right mindfulness, which belongs to the mind and always contemplates the Way;
The second practice is right speech, which belongs to the mouth and cuts off the four intentions;
The third practice is right contemplation, which belongs to the body and contemplates the inside and outside of the body;
The fourth practice is right view and faith in the Way;
The fifth practice is right action, not following the four evils, namely the four inverted views;
The sixth practice is right governance, cutting off the remaining intentions;
The seventh practice is right non-falling into greed and desire;
The eighth practice is right concentration and correct mind, which are the eight practices.
They are not practiced by Buddhas, pratyekabuddhas, or arhats.
The first practice is right mindfulness.
What is right mindfulness?
It means not thinking of myriad things, and the mind does not fall into them. This is right mindfulness;
If one's thoughts fall into the middle, it is not right mindfulness.
The four foundations of mindfulness are:

The first foundation of mindfulness is mindfulness of the breath in the body, the second foundation of mindfulness is mindfulness of feelings, the third foundation of mindfulness is mindfulness of the mind's coming and going, and the fourth foundation of mindfulness is mindfulness of the causes and conditions of phenomena. These are the four foundations of mindfulness.
Practitioners should be mindful of these four foundations of mindfulness:
First, because I have loved my body in past lives, I have not been able to escape;
Second, there are now fierce enemies.
Why is this?
What is desired is love and birth, which should be cut off. This is the external body contemplation and cessation.

The four foundations of mindfulness, the foundation of mindfulness, the mind is not in the body, the mind is stopped, it is not in feelings, the mind is stopped, it is not in the mind, the mind is stopped, it is not in phenomena, the mind is stopped.
Following the appearance of form, it is born, this is not stopping.
Question:
Why do people not fall into the four foundations of mindfulness?
Reply:
By not contemplating suffering, emptiness, non-self, and impurity, one does not fall into the four foundations of mindfulness.

If a person always contemplates suffering, emptiness, non-self, and impurity, and always contemplates these four things without separation while practicing the path, then one will quickly attain the four foundations of mindfulness.
Question:
What are the foundations of mindfulness of the body?
Contemplating old age, sickness, and death is called the foundations of mindfulness of the body.
What are the foundations of mindfulness of feelings?
What is undesirable is called the foundations of mindfulness of feelings.
What are the foundations of mindfulness of the mind?
What has been contemplated and will be contemplated is called the foundations of mindfulness of the mind.
What are the foundations of mindfulness of dharmas?

What was practiced in the past and what will be repaid in the future are called dharmas, and what is done and what is obtained are also called dharmas. This is called the foundations of mindfulness of dharmas.
The four foundations of mindfulness have four types:
First, the foundation of mindfulness of impermanence;
Second, the foundation of mindfulness of the suffering of the body;
Third, the foundation of mindfulness of emptiness;
Fourth, to contemplate the unpleasant and joyful mind, these are the four foundations of mindfulness.
All worldly matters fall into the body, feelings, and phenomena, and do not go beyond these four things.
The four foundations of mindfulness are:
First, only to contemplate the breath without deviant thoughts;
Second, only to contemplate goodness and not evil;
Third, to contemplate that the body is not one's own, and all things are not one's own, and then not to be attached;
Fourth, the eyes do not see forms, and the mind is in the Dharma. These are called the four foundations of mindfulness.
Monastics should practice the four foundations of mindfulness:
First, when the eyes see forms, one should contemplate the impurities in the body;
Second, when the mind is joyful and thinks of pleasure, one should contemplate the suffering of feelings;
Third, if one's mind is angry with others, others' minds are also angry;
If one's mind turns others, others' minds also turn, and then one does not turn the mind again;
Fourth, if one's mind envies others, others' minds also envy;
If I think ill of others, others will also think ill of me. Then I will no longer think [ill of others]. This is the Dharma.
As for the body and mind being still, one observes one's own body and the bodies of others.
What is the body?
If one says that pain and itching are the body, pain is innumerable;
If one says that the mind is the body, the body does not have the past mind or the future mind;
If one says that the Dharma is the body, the body does not have the past or future Dharma;
If one says that action is the body, action has no form, and one knows it is not the body.
Attaining this calculation is the four intentions and stops.
The mind does not fall into the thought of form, and consciousness also does not arise. The ears, nose, mouth, and body are also like this.
The mind is not in the body, and the mind is not in pain and itching. The mind is not in thought, and the mind is not in the Dharma. This is the mind.
Question:
Who is the master that knows the body, mind, pain, and itching?
Reply:
There is a body, and the mind of the body knows;
Pain and itchiness, one should know the mind of pain and itchiness;
The mind of intention, one should know the mind of intention;ğŸ”½When hungry, one should know the mind of hunger;
When thirsty, one should know the mind of thirst;ğŸ”½When cold, one should know the mind of cold;
When hot, one should know the mind of heat.
This is how one should know by distinguishing.

The mind of the body arises from the mind of the body, the mind of pain and itchiness arises from the mind of pain and itchiness, the mind of intention arises from the mind of intention, and the mind of dharmas arises from the mind of dharmas.
The four bases of mindfulness are as follows: When the mind thinks of evil, one should restrain it and not let it arise. This is called stopping.
The four bases of mindfulness also follow the four dhyÄnas, and also follow the four bases of mindfulness.
Following the four bases of mindfulness is to be close to the path, not attached to evil, and good thoughts arise.
The four dhyÄnas are the four bases of concentration, which are to stop the mind.
There are four causes and conditions for practicing the path:
First, stopping the body;
Second, stopping pain and itchiness;
Third, stopping the mind;
Fourth, stopping dharmas.
Stopping the body means seeing form and thinking of impurity;
Stopping pain and itching means not being self-important;
Stopping the mind means stopping from being angry;
Stopping the Dharma means not doubting the practice of the Way.
The four intentions stop, the mind arises and thoughts are born, and immediately consciousness opposes and practices the medicine. Obtaining one intention is to obtain the four intentions.
The four intentions are:
First, observing one's own body, also observing the bodies of others;
Second, observing one's own pain and itching, also observing the pain and itching of others;
Third, observing one's own mind, also observing the minds of others;
Fourth, observing the causes and conditions of one's own Dharma, also observing the causes and conditions of others' Dharma.

Thus, the body observes the internal and external causes and conditions, the events of formation and destruction. One should think of one's own body, which will also form and destroy. This is the four intentions.
If a person wants to stop the four intentions, abandoning the external and gathering the internal;
Having gathered the external intentions, abandoning the internal.

Observing others' bodies means that when one observes one's own body as not separate from others, one then observes others' bodies as suffering, and observes others' bodies as not being pain or itchiness, and the same is so for intention and dharmas.
When one is attached to one's own body, one should observe others' bodies;
When one is mindful of others' bodies, one should observe one's own body. This is how to practice mental stopping.
Question:
What is meant by stopping the activities of the mind?
Answer:
When the mind observes one's own body and is attached to it, one should make it observe others' bodies, because the mind turns towards attachment;
If the mind is attached to others' bodies, one should return to observe one's own body.
Sometimes one observes one's own body but not others' bodies;
Sometimes one should observe others' bodies but not one's own body;
Sometimes one can observe both one's own body and others' bodies;
Sometimes one cannot observe either one's own body or others' bodies.
Observing one's own body means to contemplate the bodies of others, but the mind is not yet still. One should think of one's own body as attached, and then turn to attach to the bodies of others.

Observing the bodies of others, one sees their flesh, whiteness, eyebrows, and red lips. Seeing flesh, one should think of a bloated corpse. Seeing whiteness, one should think of a corpse's bones. Seeing black eyebrows, one should think of a corpse's blackness. Seeing red lips, one should think of blood's redness.
Contemplating all that exists in the body, one attains this mind and then turns it, no longer loving the body.
Observing what is internal and external, jealousy, anger, and doubt should be internally observed, while greed and lust should be externally observed.
Greed should be thought of as impermanent and decaying, while lust should be thought of as the impurity of all that exists.
Like observing one's own body and lust, one should think of the four intentions for cutting off.
There are two types of observation:
First, observing the outside;
Second, observing the inside.
Observing the body as having thirty-six substances, all that is opposed is external;
Contemplating the absence of anything as the path is the inner contemplation.
There are three things in contemplation:
First, contemplating the four colors of the body, namely black, blue, red, and white;
Second, contemplating birth and death;
Third, contemplating the nine paths.
Contemplating black when seeing white is impurity. One should first hear and then attain the path later;
If one has not attained the path, it is for the sake of hearing, distinguishing, realizing, and knowing.
There are four kinds of contemplation:
First, contemplation of the body;
Second, contemplation of the mind;
Third, contemplation of practice;
Fourth, contemplation of the path. These are the four contemplations.
It is like a person guarding things. When a thief comes, they immediately abandon the things;
After observing the thief, they attain contemplation and then abandon the contemplation of the body and things.
There are two things in contemplation:
First, contemplating the various external forms;
Second, contemplating the internal, namely the absence of anything.

Having attained the four dhyÄnas through contemplating emptiness, contemplating emptiness as having no existence, with intention and no intention, no existence, this is emptiness, also called attaining the four dhyÄnas through the four abandonments.
If one wishes to sever worldly matters, one should practice the four right efforts. If one wishes to eliminate the four right efforts, one should practice the four bases of supernatural power.
When a person falls into craving, they act out of craving.

The four bases of supernatural power enable one to fly, but if one only has the five faculties and not the five powers, one cannot control them. If one only has the five powers and not the five faculties, they do not arise.
Having attained the four bases of supernatural power, one can still transform the five powers and control them. The next twelve items are the four bases of supernatural power.
The four right efforts do not create present offenses, but only finish past offenses. This is the four right efforts.

Finishing the old and not accepting the new is the four bases of mindfulness. Therefore, finishing the old and stopping the new is the four right efforts. Therefore, finishing the new and cutting off the old is the four bases of supernatural power.
Knowing contentment, not seeking again, guarding the mind, the mind is completed. Birth is new, old age is old, death is the body decaying and perishing.
The four right efforts are always contemplating the Way.
When good thoughts arise, evil thoughts are cut off, so it is the path of cutting off.
When good thoughts cease, evil thoughts arise, so it is not cutting off.
The four right efforts are the mind itself not wanting to turn to evil, which is cutting off, and also not thinking of cutting off offenses.
The four bases of supernatural power:
First, the base of supernatural power of the body;
Second, the base of supernatural power of speech;
Third, the base of supernatural power of the mind;
Fourth, the base of supernatural power of the Way.
Contemplating flying, contemplating not wanting to extinguish, not following the Way.
The four bases of supernatural power, four is the number, iti is stopping, and ba is the base.
If one wants to fly, one flies. Sometimes one sits in concentration for seven days and then attains it, sometimes for seven days, sometimes for seven years.
Attaining the supernormal powers, one can remain in the world for a long time, and there is medicine for not dying:
First, the mind does not change;
Second, faith;
Third, mindfulness;
Fourth, having truth;
Fifth, having wisdom - these are the medicines for the supernormal powers.
Attaining the four supernormal powers, one does not remain in the world for a long time, for three reasons:
First, one is disgusted with one's own foul body, so one leaves;
Second, there is no one who can receive the sutras and teachings from one, so one leaves;
Third, fearing that evil people will slander and incur offenses, so one leaves.
The supernormal powers are of nine kinds, referring to riding in a carriage or on horseback, and running fast on foot, which are also supernormal powers;
Upholding the precepts is also a supernormal power;ğŸ”½Sincerity is also a supernormal power;
Forbearance is also a supernormal power.
Practicing the supernormal powers should be done with a flying mind.
Question:
What is a flying mind?
Answer:
There are four causes and conditions:
First, faith;
Second, diligence;
Third, concentration;
Fourth, unwavering intention.
What is faith?
Faith is flying.
What is diligence?
Flying.
What is concentration?
Flying.
What is an unwavering intention?
It means an unwavering intention to fly.
If the body does not wish to practice the path, but the mind wishes to practice and then practices, the spiritual powers are like this, and if the mind wishes to fly, it can fly.
The five faculties are like planting things; they grow roots if firm, and have no roots if not firm.
Faith is like water and rain, an unwavering intention is like strength, what is seen is like roots, and controlling the mind is like strength.
Within the faculty of faith, there are three aggregates:
The first is pain and itching, the second is thought, and the third is the aggregate of consciousness.
Within the faculty of concentration, there is one aggregate, namely the aggregate of consciousness.

The five faculties, five powers, and seven factors of awakening, within them there are those with one aggregate, those with two aggregates, those with three aggregates, and those with four aggregates, all have aggregates.
Question:
For this practice of the path, what conditions are there for having aggregates?
Reply:
Because nirvana is without aggregates, the rest all have aggregates.
The seven factors of awakening, the upper three factors belong to speech, the middle three factors belong to the body, and the lower one factor belongs to the mind.
What are the factors?
Moment to moment is a factor, moment to moment is attainment, realizing this intention is following the path.
The external seven factors of awakening fall into birth and death, the internal seven factors of awakening follow the path.
The internal seven factors of awakening refer to the sutras of the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment;
The external seven factors of awakening refer to the myriad things.
Awakening is recognizing events, then following the factors of awakening.
There are factors of awakening that follow the path of awakening, and there are factors of awakening that fall into the awakening of offenses.
The thirty-seven factors of enlightenment are the correct intention, which is following the path;
Realizing good and evil is falling into offenses.
Question:
What is meant by the retribution of upholding the body and mind according to the truths?
It means upholding the seven precepts of the body and the three precepts of the mind, which is upholding the body and mind.
The mind obtains rest according to the truths, and rests due to the causes and conditions of the four truths;
Resting is cessation, and resting is contemplation, which is receiving contemplation by attaining the path.

Delighting in the Dharma of the path, always practicing the path is the mindfulness of love, upholding the path without losing it is the mindfulness of power, already attaining the ten cessations and bodily peace is the mindfulness of cessation, and knowing one's own peace is the mindfulness of concentration.
Upholding the body and mind, the mind does not wander and is upheld, according to the truths one is free, and the mind is at ease wherever it goes, which is attaining the four truths.

One can also contemplate the four foundations of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, five powers, seven factors of enlightenment, and eightfold path. This is called the mind of freedom.
Wherever one practices, following true contemplation, is the essence of the thirty-seven chapters of the sutra.
This is called guarding the mind and being mindful, which means not to receive suffering again.

The eightfold path has internal and external aspects. The body is killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct. Speech is slander, harsh words, false speech, and frivolous talk. The mind is covetousness, ill-will, and ignorance.
These first three dharmas are the ten matters that are external, while the five paths are internal.
Following truth and guarding truth, following is spirit, guarding is protection, which means not committing offenses according to the Dharma.
Truth is the path. Knowing impermanence, suffering, emptiness, non-self, and impurity is right view;

Those who are impermanent consider themselves permanent, think of suffering as happiness, consider emptiness as existence, use the non-body as the body, and consider the impure as pure. This is called wrong view.
What is right view?
Belief in the fundamental causes and conditions, knowing that they exist from past lives, this is called right view.
What is right practice?
Discerning and contemplating, able to reach good intentions, this is called right practice.
What is right speech?
Upholding good words, not violating the Dharma, speaking as one should, this is called right speech.
What is right action?
The body should act without violating action, this is called right action.
What is right livelihood?
Following the teachings and precepts of those who have attained the Way, this is called right livelihood.
What is right effort?
Practicing without attachment, day and night without stopping, not abandoning skillful means, this is called right effort and skillful means.
What is right mindfulness?
Always facing the sutras and precepts, this is called right mindfulness.
What is right concentration?
The mind is neither confused nor abandons practice, this is called right concentration.
Practicing like this, it causes the eight practices of the noble ones to be complete. Having already practiced and been fulfilled, one then practices the path.
The eight rightnesses have governance and practice. Practicing the eight rightnesses, one is then able to attain liberation. The body does not violate the precepts, this is called right governance.
Wisdom, faith, and patience are called the body of practice. The mind upholding is called right governance.
It is said that having nothing to think about is right, having something to think about is not right.
The twelve divisions of the canon all fall within the thirty-seven chapters of the sutra, just as the myriad streams and four rivers all return to the great ocean.
The thirty-seven chapters of the sutra are the outer, and contemplation is the inner.
Contemplation gives rise to the path, so it is the inner;
When a practitioner practices the path, distinguishing the thirty-seven chapters of the sutra, this is called paying homage to the Buddha.
The thirty-seven factors of enlightenment also fall into the world and also fall into the Way.
Reciting the sutra and speaking it is the world, and thinking about it with the mind is in accord with the Way.
Upholding precepts is for regulating the body, and meditation is for dispersing the mind.
Practice follows vows, and vows also follow practice.
When practicing the Way, the mind does not depart;
When the mind reaches the Buddha, it does not return.
There are those who attain the Way through gradual practice, and there are those who attain the Way without gradual practice.

That is to say, practicing the four foundations of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of enlightenment, and the eightfold path is gradual.
Fearing the evils of the world, the body then attains the Way in a single thought, which is not gradual.
A practitioner who can attain the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment does not necessarily follow counting the breath, following, or stopping.
The seven matters of body and speech, and the mind, thought, and consciousness each have ten matters, thus making thirty-seven factors.

The four foundations of mindfulness, the four right efforts, and the four bases of supernatural power belong to the external, while the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of awakening, and the eightfold path lead to the attainment of the Way.
Nirvana has forty categories, namely the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment and the three directions, totaling forty matters, all of which lead to nirvana.
Question:

Counting the breath does not lead to nirvana. Counting the breath and following the breath, stopping the mind at the tip of the nose and becoming attached to something, does not lead to nirvana. Is there nirvana or not?
Answer:
Nirvana is non-existence, but it is the cessation of suffering, also called the exhaustion of the mind.
Objection:
Nirvana is extinction.
Answer:
It is only the extinction of good and evil.

The practitioner knows when to practice the four foundations of mindfulness, when to practice the four right efforts, when to practice the four bases of supernatural power, and when to practice the five faculties, five powers, seven factors of awakening, and eightfold path.
The truth is to know concentration and distraction.
Concentration is knowing, and distraction is not knowing.
Question:
Why are there precisely five faculties, five powers, seven factors of enlightenment, and eightfold path?
Answer:
People have five faculties, and the path has five faculties;
People have five powers, and the path has five powers;
People have seven kinds of defilements, and the path has seven factors of enlightenment;
There are eight kinds of practice that correspond to the eightfold path.
The medicine is taught according to the illness, and the causes and conditions correspond.
The eye receives form, the ear hears sounds, the nose smells fragrances, the mouth desires flavors, and the body craves smoothness. These are the five faculties.
Why are they called faculties?

Because they have already received and will receive again, they are called faculties. Not receiving form, sound, fragrance, flavor, or smoothness, this is power. Not falling into the seven kinds of defilements is the factor of enlightenment. The eightfold path is the practice that corresponds.

The five faculties are the firm intention, the five powers are the irreversible intention, the seven factors of enlightenment are the correct intention, and the eightfold path is the straight intention.
Question:
What is meant by good thoughts?
What is meant by the thoughts of the Way?
Reply:
The four intentions, four bases of mindfulness, four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, and five powers are called good thoughts;
The seven factors of awakening and eightfold path are called the thoughts of the Way.
There is the good of the Way and the good of the world.
From the four bases of mindfulness to the five faculties and five powers is the good of the Way;
Not engaging in sexual misconduct, divisive speech, harsh speech, false speech, frivolous speech, greed, hatred, or delusion is the good of the world.
The view of the truth is knowing that all things will perish, this is the view of the truth;
The destruction of all things and the death of the body, not taking it to be a cause for worry, is the contemplation of the truth.
When the mind runs wild, one should immediately restrain it, this is the elimination of offenses;
Not accepting any evil that comes is meditation.

The twelve internal mental activities are: 1. counting, 2. following, 3. stopping, 4. observing, 5. returning, 6. purifying, 7. wisdom, 8. number, 9. characteristics, 10. abiding, 11. contemplation, and 12. purity. These are the twelve internal activities.

The twelve external activities are: 1. eyes, 2. forms, 3. ears, 4. sounds, 5. nose, 6. smells, 7. mouth, 8. tastes, 9. body, 10. tactile objects, 11. mind, and 12. desires. These are the twelve external activities.

1. Knowing one's parents, siblings, and spouses from countless past lives;
2. Knowing the good and bad, long and short of countless past lives, and knowing what others are thinking in their hearts;
